awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research on Learning and Tteaching at the Physics-Mathematics Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a project to investigate the development of undergraduate students' mathematical understanding in the context of learning physics, particularly while solving challenging upper-division physics problems. The project team will conduct an integrated program of research, curriculum development, and assessment of topics covering a typical sophomore- or junior-level course in mathematical methods. The broad goals are to conduct research on student resources, study the process of transfer from mathematics to physics and the coevolution of knowledge in the two disciplines, and develop a set of Math / Physics tasks suitable for instruction, research, and assessment materials that will integrate challenging math content with topics covered in upper-division physics core courses.  This project has the potential to impact a gateway course to the upper division for physics majors.  Curricular materials will be shared through electronic clearinghouses and via published research and it is anticipated that the project will inform instruction - both of math methods courses and subsequent physics courses in which the mathematics is used - nationally and internationally. The student population at California State University Fullerton includes many students from groups traditionally underrepresented in physics, so this project will provide access to research-based materials for these students and also ensure a diverse research population. 

This interdisciplinary project brings together physics education research (PER) and research in undergraduate math education (RUME). It blends efforts at identifying and addressing student conceptual difficulties in physics with efforts toward understanding knowledge transfer in mathematics. The work targets a key course for physics majors, the mathematical methods course that is offered in most departments at the sophomore- or junior-level. This course is typically intended to be a bridge between introductory physics and calculus courses and the more challenging mathematics and physics encountered by students in the core courses of electricity and magnetism, classical mechanics, and modern physics / quantum mechanics. The project will strengthen the research base in a portion of the curriculum that has, to this point, largely gone unexamined, and will touch upon, and build upon, work in several related areas, including PER in other upper-division courses as well as the extensive research base in undergraduate mathematics education. This proposed work will provide significant insights into transfer by probing the extent to which the nature of student understanding depends upon the disciplinary context. The research team has many years' experience in PER and RUME and have collaborated on successful research and curriculum development projects at the upper division in thermal physics and the physics-mathematics interface.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project have been:

  • to conduct research on student understanding in mathematics and upper-division physics,
  • to study transfer from mathematics to physics and the coevolution of knowledge in the two disciplines, and
  • to develop a set of Math/Physics tasks that integrate challenging math content with topics covered in upper-division physics core courses. 

There are three intellectual threads through the work: research on student understanding of physics and mathematics concepts; research on knowledge transfer, specifically from mathematics to physics; and development and assessment of instructional resources.  The primary focus of the work has been the course often known as "math methods," a course for physics majors intended to develop mathematical tools used in other upper-division theory courses. 

The transfer portion of the project was largely the province of original collaborating PI Joseph Wagner at Xavier University. Dr. Wagner left academia in the second project year, causing a change of emphasis. This transfer portion is touched upon in some publications, but without Wagner the emphasis shifted to the other two goals.

The research portion of the project was driven by student researchers at all institutions, contributing to both intellectual merit and broader impacts (through training and capacity building). In conjunction with faculty advisors, several students at our three institutions have conducted research with an emphasis on the following topics:

  • student use of evaluation strategies (e.g., unit checks, dimensional analysis), both locally and quasi-longitudinally
  • student conceptions of functions in physics contexts
  • student conceptions of integration in physics contexts
  • student understanding of unit vectors, particularly in non-Cartesian coordinates
  • student understanding of differential vector elements (length, area, volume)
  • student understanding of Fourier series
  • student understanding of matrix multiplication and eigentheory, in quantum mechanics and other contexts
  • student understanding of Dirac notation and vector spaces in quantum mechanics
  • student understanding of simple ordinary differential equations

The students supported by this project include three completed PhDs (Schermerhorn and Akinyemi UMaine, Farlow NDSU), two completed MS degrees (Vega and Mays CSUF), and eight undergraduate researchers. Two CSUF students whose undergraduate research was supported by this grant are currently in PhD programs. The majority of the students supported by the grant are members of groups traditionally underrepresented in physics.

UMaine PI Thompson taught the upper-division quantum mechanics course multiple times; Thompson and graduate students who sat in to observe developed and tested instructional resources throughout the course. These materials included "clicker" questions intended for large-group discussions, long-form worksheets for small group work, and shorter worksheets adaptable to either. In addition, several exercises suitable for homework were developed and tested. Various theoretical frameworks, including symbolic forms and mathematical sensemaking, were extended and applied in the research, development, and analysis.

UMaine-centered efforts focused on 3-D, non-Cartesian coordinate system differential quantities (length, area, volume); evaluation strategies across problems and across different levels; and eigenequations and notation in quantum mechanics.

We used the symbolic forms theoretical framework to track how students construct differential elements in non-Cartesian coordinate systems. Our interview protocol for a length differential worked well both to elicit individual steps and student thinking and to help students recognize an error and address the issue; that protocol was modified to be an in-class small-group activity. Results are consistent with earlier literature but demonstrate the utility of the framework to a more sophisticated context with relevance in mathematics and physics.

In evaluation strategies, we found that introductory students tend to rederive an expression to check whether it is reasonable - start from first principles - rather than use expert-like checks such as special or limiting cases or dimensional analysis. Data from the upper division indicates that this tendency shifts to more explicitly expert strategies as well as making approximations and more qualitative checks. A specific strategy named "grouping" has been identified and documented wherein students recognize physical significance in groups of terms in an expression (e.g., a mass*volume being momentum, or the terms in a Coulomb potential) to interpret the expression.

Work in quantum mechanics was somewhat preliminary in this project, but yielded promising ideas. We looked at how students interpret various quantum mechanical quantities and expressions, particularly in Dirac notation, which was developed to express these quantities more elegantly and efficiently but has a large cognitive overhead and requires a rudimentary understanding of vector spaces and eigentheory. Analysis of results is ongoing and will continue into a subsequent grant.

This work has been widely disseminated to the physics education research (PER) and research in undergraduate math education (RUME) communities, collectively leading to four journal articles, 11 peer-reviewed conference proceedings in PER and RUME, eight invited presentations, and over 50 contributed talks and posters. Another two to six journal articles are in preparation and/or anticipated. In addition, the project team led three invited talk or poster sessions and two working groups at national meetings.
